text:
Robots exhibition at the Science Museum, London – in pictures Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email View more sharing options Share on LinkedIn Share on Pinterest Share on Google+ Share on WhatsApp Share on Messenger Close 
A new exhibition opening on 8 February, Robots is a collection of over 100 objects ranging from 16th century automata to cutting-edge ‘emotional’ robots
Ian Sample and Eric Hilaire 
Tuesday 7 February 2017 07.00 GMT 

A robotic baby lies on an illuminated “mattress” at the entrance to the Science Museum’s Robots exhibition. The nappy-wearing robot appears to breathe, moves its arms and legs, and opens and closes its eyes. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

The robotic baby is controlled by a system of cables and actuators that are revealed to visitors as they walk past the exhibit. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

A replica of Maria from Fritz Lang’s 1927 silent film, Metropolis. Her face evokes the golden mask of Tutankhamun, discovered five years before her creation, yet she also inspired future robots, including C3PO from the Star Wars series. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

The 2.5m tall, half tonne Cygan was built in 1957 by the Italian engineer Piero Fiorito. After a glitzy career as a performer, he became the mascot for an Essex car dealership and then languished outside at the Southend Historic Aircraft Museum. He was eventually salvaged and restored. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

Since the late 1930s, Japan has dominated the market for tin robots. While some boast guns, lasers and even rocket launchers, others incorporate more mundane technologies, including television screens and motor car engines. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

Toy robots helped to reinforce the view that robots should have a humanoid form and be tall, broad-shouldered and powerful – unlike many of the robots that had begun to appear in factories around the world. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

A T-800 endoskeleton used in the 1991 film Terminator 2: Judgment Day. One of the most terrifying robot villains to date, it has contributed to preconceptions of what robots might become. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

Engineers are experimenting with robots that are modelled on the human musculoskeletal system. The robots can move just like humans, but in time experience familiar problems, such as worn out joints. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

Inkha is the sassy robotic receptionist that greeted visitors to King’s College London, from 2003 until 2015. All eyes and lips, the robot dispensed directions, information and plenty of attitude when its sarcasm setting was turned up. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

Developed in Spain in 2016, REEM is a host and tour guide that can safely interact with people face to face. It can navigate independently in new environments using sound, laser, infrared and incline sensors. It is one of a growing range of service robots that may one day work alongside humans in places ranging from hospitals to shopping centres. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

RoboThespian was the first full-sized humanoid robot that anyone could buy. The £50,000 metal man can tell jokes and perform songs and plays in one of thirty languages. The robot uses its expressive eyes and body language to engage with its audience. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 

One of the world’s most advanced humanoid robots, iCub is designed to learn like a human toddler. Over the past 10 years, the robot has worked out how to sit up, crawl, reach for objects and use them. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian
